Syngas conversion to long chain alcohols and aldehydes by Co-based catalysts offers green route for synthesizing value-added chemicals. Cobalt carbides (Co2C) has been proven promoting oxygenates formation, and the Co/Co2C interface exhibited synergetic effects on increasing selectivity of higher alcohols. However, the underlying mechanism that determines the ratio of aldehydes and alcohols in oxygenate products is less understood. In this work, the hydrogenation of oxygenate intermediate was studied from first principles on metallic Co, Co2C surfaces and Co/Co2C interface to investigate the formation processes of alcohols and aldehydes. First-principles calculations show that: On Co2C(111) facet of Co2C nanosphere, aldehyde desorption as the final product has a slight advantage over its subsequent hydrogenation to alcohol; hydrogenation of oxygenate on Co2C(020) facet of Co2C nanoprism is difficult, whereas aldehyde on Co2C(101) facet of Co2C nanoprism is very easy to be hydrogenated to alcohol; and the synergistic effect between metallic and carbide surfaces on the Co/Co2C interface model promotes the selectivity of alcohol as the final product during hydrogenation of oxygenate intermediates. This study provides theoretical insights into the rational design of catalysts for controlling the selectivity between aldehydes and alcohols in syngas conversion to oxygenates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Syngas conversion Co2C Alcohols Aldehydes Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) is a process that converts syngas derived from coal, natural gas, and biomass into hydrocarbons, providing a non-petroleum route for the production of synthetic fuels. This green and reliable process has significant industrial, economic, and social value for the manufacture of fossil fuel alternatives. Co-based catalyst is one of the major FTS catalysts in industrial applications, producing primarily long-chain alkanes with a trace of olefins and higher alcohols. In traditional FTS research, it is generally believed that metal Co0 is the active phase of CO hydrogenation, whereas the oxides or carbides, generated under reaction conditions, are considered to be the deactivation components[1]. However, recent researches have demonstrated that cobalt carbide (Co2C) plays an important role in the direct conversion of syngas into olefins, which is known as Fischer-Tropsch to Olefins (FTO)[2–4] process. During their investigations on the CoMn FTO catalysts, Zhong et al. [5,6]. discovered that a previously unreported prism-like Co2C was formed during the reaction, they named it Co2C nanoprism. Due to the distinctive surface structure, the exposed (101) and (020) facets on the Co2C nanoprism are favorable in promoting olefin production and inhibiting methane formation. In addition to Co2C nanoprism, another Co2C active phase, Co2C nanosphere with (111) facet dominantly exposed, has been discovered, which exhibited high selectivity for N-aldehydes and N-alcohols via FTS from syngas[7]. With the general recognition of the outstanding selectivity in higher alcohols synthesis (HAS), several studies on the investigation of stable bulk Co2C have been reported[5,8,9]. Moreover, experimental studies have pointed that Co2C can be partially decomposed into Co0 under the typical FTS temperature (∼493 K)[10–12]. It is acknowledged that the Co/Co2C bifunctional sites promote oxygenates formation, where metallic Co site contributed to CO activation and Co2C site were responsible for the formation of oxygenate intermediates[13,14]. Ding et al. [10]. has successfully synthesized the SiO2‐supported Co2C catalyst, which showed the highest CO conversion (43.9%) and alcohol selectivity (65.6%). Sun et al. [11]. found that the selectivity of oxygenates by the Na-promoted CoMn exceeded 20% under HAS conditions, mainly alcohols and aldehydes, of which C2+ accounted for more than 90% and C6+ accounted for roughly 50%. In order to understand the reaction mechanism of HAS on dual sites, Li and co-workers et al. [15]. constructed Co(0001)/Co2C(111) interface. Their results prove that Co2C(111) is responsible for the non-dissociative activation of CO and subsequent insertion into alkyl chains to form oxygenate intermediates, while the Co(0001) surface offers active sites for CO dissociative adsorption and chain propagation. In addition to alcohols, aldehydes is another kind of oxygenates that can be produced by Co2C nanosphere. In the investigation into K-promoted CoMn HAS catalysts by Kruse group[7], the selectivity of oxygenates is usually >50 wt.%, among which aldehydes accounts for more than 97%. Based on these discussions, Co2C can be used as an active phase for the synthesis of alcohols and aldehydes due to the unique surface properties. The results of the current catalyst test suggest that the direct conversion of syngas into high value-added fine chemicals[16] is a rational and promising route for cleanly and efficiently utilizing coal resources. With the rapid development of molecular simulation, it has been used as a tool to elucidate the mechanisms of typical reactions and catalysts. There have been some theoretical studies on FTS[17,18] and HAS reactions catalyzed by Co2C or Co/Co2C. Co2C(101) surface is in favor of the hydrocarbons formation[19], while Co2C(111) benefited CO insertion and the formation of Co/Co2C(111) as dual active sites contributed to the enhancement of oxygenates selectivity. In the study on the formation of oxygenates catalyzed by Co2C, the theoretical research mainly focused on CO activation[20,21], CHx coupling and CO insertion on the surfaces of Co or Co2C, with the formation of oxygenate compound intermediates (CHxCO*) as the end point[22–25]. Up to now, there is little research on the process of continuous hydrogenation, like alcohols and aldehydes, to the final product. Therefore, this study intends to using DFT calculations to investigate the roles of Co2C facets to the progress of CHxCO* continue hydrogenation to alcohol or aldehyde and describe the selectivity differences of products by comparing reaction barriers. Further, by exploring the special location of hydrogenation at the Co/Co2C interface to probe the synergistic effect of Co and Co2C. The results may provide guidance for the rational design of catalysts and process design of products dominated by alcohols or aldehydes. 2 Computations details 2.1 Methods All spin-polarized DFT calculations in this work were performed with the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP), using projector augmented wave (PAW) method and a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff kinetic energy of 400 eV was employed. For all calculations in this work, the generalized gradient approximation with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof functional (PBE) was used, and the density of the Monkhorst-Pack k-point samplings was kept at ∼ 0.04 Å −1. A 3 × 3 × 1 k-points is performed for sampling the Brillouin-zone integration to calculate surface slab. The geometry optimization would be converged when the energy difference was smaller than 1 × 10−5 eV, and the forces were less than 0.03 eV/Å. The transition state (TS) was determined by climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) and DIMER methods. All transition states were confirmed by frequency analysis. All energies were corrected by Zero Point Energy (ZPE), and the Gibbs free energy is obtained by entropy correction. In this paper, the reaction energy (ΔG) is defined as the Gibbs free energy difference between the initial state (IS) and the final state (FS) of the surface reaction intermediate. The Gibbs free energy barrier (Ea) of the surface reaction, or called as the activation energy, is calculated by the difference between the Gibbs free energy of the transition state (TS) and IS. In addition, the adsorption energy of surface species is defined as Eads = E (adsorbate+surface) –Eadsorbate - Esurface, where E (adsorbate+surface) represents the total energy of the interaction between adsorbate and surface, Eadsorbate and Esurface represent the total energy of adsorbate molecules in the gas phase and the total energy of the clean catalyst surface model, respectively. In addition, the kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) was performed to estimate the reaction rate and selectivity of products under typical FTS reaction conditions (T = 493∼533 K, P = 4 MPa). More details were presented in supporting information. 2.2 Models The cobalt carbide surface model is constructed based on the optimized Co2C cell. Co-terminated Co2C facets are typical structure under hydrogen-rich conditions so that we choose the models with cobalt as the termination surface[26,27]. The calculated lattice parameters of Co2C are a = 2.869 Å, b = 4.353 Å and c = 4.358 Å, which are consistent with the previously reported values[22,28]. Based on this lattice, p(2 × 2–111), p(2 × 2–101) and p(2 × 3–020) crystal planes were constructed. The vacuum layer is fixed at 15 Å, and each model contains at least four Co and C atomic layers, the top two Co layers and the corresponding C layers relaxation. The optimized surface models are shown in Fig. 1 . The metal Co surface model was established based on the hexagonal close-packed Co cell. The optimized cell parameters are as follows: a = 2.496 Å, b = 2.496 Å and c = 4.015 Å. The p(3 × 3–0001) surface was constructed and the bottom two atoms are fixed. According to the experiments and HRTEM images of pei et al. [15]., Co2C will be partially decomposed into Co under the FTS conditions, leading to an interface between Co and Co2C. Based on the HRTEM images, we have constructed two Co atoms wide stripe on p(2 × 2)-Co2C(111) surface to investigate the role of the interface between Co and Co2C on the synthesis of C2 oxygenates[23]. The Co/Co2C interface, based on the prior experimental and modeling results, was built according to the model shown in Fig. 2 . It is represented by the interface between the hexagonal close-packed Co atom placed on the Co2C surface and the Co2C(111) surface. 3 Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 3 , three main pathways can lead to the formation of aldehyde (RCHO) or alcohol (RCOH) intermediates through the hydrogenation of oxygenate compound intermediates (RCO). RCO hydrogenation can occur through two pathways, resulting in the formation of RCHO or RCOH intermediates. The RCHO produced from RCO hydrogenation can undergo four subsequent processes: (1) RCHO desorption, leading to the formation of aldehydes as the final product; (2) Hydrogenation of the α-C of RCHO to RCH2O, which further undergoes hydrogenation to produce RCH2OH, then desorbed as the final product (Path 1); (3) Hydrogenation of the O atom of RCHO to RCHOH, which can be further hydrogenated to form RCH2OH, resulting in the production of alcohols (Path 2). In Path 3, hydrogenation of RCO to RCOH, followed by further hydrogenation to RCHOH, and ultimately obtaining RCH2OH (Path 3). To better understand the key reactions involved, CH3 is used instead of R to investigate the formation mechanism of ethanol and acetaldehyde on different surfaces. Energy changes of α-alcohol (ethanol as an example) generated on the (111) surface of Co2C nanosphere and the (020) and (101) surfaces of Co2C nanoprism were computed through three routes using RCO as the starting point (Fig. 4 ). The relevant reaction equations are as follows: (1) CH3CO∗ + H ∗ → CH3CHO∗ +∗ (2) CH3CHO∗ + H ∗ → CH3CH2O∗ +∗ (3) CH3CH2O∗ + H ∗ → CH3CH2OH∗ +∗ (4) CH3CHO∗ + H ∗ → CH3CHOH∗ +∗ (5) CH3CO∗ + H ∗ → CH3COH∗ +∗ (6) CH3COH∗ + H ∗ → CH3CHOH∗ +∗ (7) CH3CHOH∗ + H ∗ → CH3CH2OH∗ +∗ 3.1 The formation mechanism of alcohol and aldehyde on Co2C(101) and (020) facets The predominant facets of Co2C nanoprism are (101) and (020). Experimental findings have demonstrated a higher propensity for olefin generation on Co2C nanoprism as opposed to oxygenated compounds[6]. However, there is currently no available evidence regarding the specific mechanism underlying the formation of oxygen-containing compounds. Therefore, this section aims to investigate the reaction mechanism of Co2C nanoprism in the production of alcohols and aldehydes. The energy curve in Fig. 4a indicates that the hydrogenation of oxygenated compound intermediates on the Co2C(020) facet is a highly endothermic process. This makes it challenging to generate hydrogenated oxygenated compound products on the surface in most cases. Along Path 1, the energy barrier for CH3CHO formation is 69 kJ/mol, and further desorption only requires 34 kJ/mol. Among all the paths, the hydrogenation of the O atom has the highest energy barrier in the hydrogenation process. The reaction energy barriers of CH3CH2O + H (Path 1), CH3CHO + H (Path 2) and CH3CO + H (Path 3) are 165, 132 and 159 kJ/mol, respectively. Subsequent hydrogenation is extremely hard, making it difficult to generate alcohols. Therefore, even though oxygenated compound products can be formed on Co2C(020), they are predominantly aldehydes. Based on the adsorption atoms and sites on the Co2C(020) surface, both the O atom and C atom of CH3CO are adsorbed on the Co-Co bridge site, and the CO bond is parallel to the plane (Fig. 5 ). In Path 1, during the hydrogenation of CH3CHO to CH3CH2O, the CO bond undergoes a transition from parallel to perpendicular to the surface. Additionally, the bond length increases from 1.36 Å to 1.47 Å, and the O atom adsorption site transitions from the bridge to the hollow site. Further hydrogenation to ethanol requires overcoming a reaction energy barrier of 168 kJ/mol and absorbing an additional heat of 128 kJ/mol. In Path 2, the H atom used to generate CH3CH2OH adsorbs on the hollow site, and the CO bond rotates by 58.7° from being parallel to the surface to being in the plane. On the Co2C (101) surface, both the C and O atoms of CH3CO are adsorbed on the Co-Co bond (Fig. 5). When CH3CHO is formed along Path 1, the C atom becomes the top adsorption site, and the CO bond length changes from 1.33 Å to 1.40 Å. However, the desorption of the aldehyde from the surface requires 86 kJ/mol, while the reaction barrier for further hydrogenation to CH3CH2O is only 4 kJ/mol, and the process is exothermic (55.5 kJ/mol). Consequently, it is hypothesized that oxygenate compounds are more likely to undergo continued hydrogenation on this surface. The reaction energy barrier for the hydrogenation of CH3CHO to CH3CHOH is 129 kJ/mol, and the heat adsorption barrier is 79 kJ/mol, with the CO bond length increasing from 1.394 Å to 1.518 Å. In comparison to the synthesis of CH3CHOH, the hydrogenation of CH3CHO tends to generate CH3CH2O along Path 1, both thermodynamically and kinetically. This intermediate exists on the surface in the form of O adsorption on the Co-Co bridge site. Furthermore, considering that Co2C(101) is a crucial component of Co2C nanoprism, it is plausible that there exists a mechanism wherein the aldehyde generated on the Co2C(020) facet re-adsorbs on the Co2C(101) facet and undergoes subsequent hydrogenation to produce alcohol. 3.2 The formation mechanism of alcohol and aldehyde on Co2C(111) facet On the Co2C(111) surface, the initial step of CH3CO hydrogenation preferentially leads to the formation of CH3CHO along Path 1 and Path 2. This particular reaction is thermodynamically favorable due to its exothermic nature, releasing 46 kJ/mol of energy. In contrast, the other pathways are endothermic. CH3CHO, with a desorption energy of 78 kJ/mol (Table 1 ), can easily detach from the system. During the first hydrogenation step, the CO bond of CH3CO is nearly parallel to the surface, and the H atom adsorbs on the hollow site. The hydroxyl H of CH3COH remains distant from the surface, while the H used to form CH3CHO is closer to the surface at a distance of 1.72 Å. This proximity might explain the ease of CH3CHO formation on Co2C(111). Compared to the hydrogenation of CH3CHO to CH3CHOH (Path 2), the formation of CH3CH2O (Path 1) is more favorable both thermodynamically and kinetically. It is an exothermic reaction with an energy release of −49 kJ/mol, accompanied by a lower reaction barrier of 17 kJ/mol for CH3CH2O formation compared to 151 kJ/mol for CH3CHOH. However, the formation of CH3CHOH requires an additional 89 kJ/mol of heat. Consequently, the further hydrogenation of CH3CHO on Co2C(111) is more inclined towards the production of CH3CH2O in terms of thermodynamics and kinetics. In Path 3, the hydrogenation of CH3COH to ethanol occurs through two steps. In the first step, the H atom adsorbs on the vacancy, while the CO bond remains parallel to the surface. However, in the resulting CH3CH2OH, the CO bond is inclined at an angle of 70.5° to the surface, and the O atom adsorbs onto the Co-Co bridge site in the second step of hydrogenation (Fig. 6 ). The synthesis of CH3CH2OH from CH3CHOH exhibits a reaction barrier of 30 kJ/mol, indicating a strong exothermic reaction with a release of 158 kJ/mol of energy. The total energy barriers for the conversion of CH3CO to CH3CH2OH on the Co2C(111) surface through various pathways are 70, 105, and 116 kJ/mol, all of which exhibit exothermic characteristics (−119, −115, and −84 kJ/mol, respectively). These values are comparatively lower than the energy barriers observed on the Co2C(020) surface (235, 220, and 238 kJ/mol) and the Co2C(101) surface (97, 194, and 184 kJ/mol). Consequently, the formation of CH3CH2OH on the Co2C(111) surface is generally considered more favorable. Furthermore, the overall energy barriers for CH3CHO desorption and hydrogenation along Path 1 are relatively similar, with values of 32 kJ/mol and 43 kJ/mol, respectively. This means that aldehydes have a high probability of continuing to hydrogenate to form alcohols. To better illustrate the selectivity of product generation, kMC simulations are used to analyze CH3CO hydrogenation under typical FTS reaction conditions. The figure S1 shows the total reaction rate and product distribution of desorbed CH3CHO and CH3CH2OH generated from CH3CO* at 493–533 K, 4 MPa. The predicted product distribution reveals that aldehydes always dominate at 493–533 K, and increasing the reaction temperature promotes more alcohols and slightly increases the formation rate. This kMC finding supports our DFT calculation that CH3CO* is more likely to hydrogenate selectively to aldehydes on the Co2C(111) surface. On all three facets, the initial step of CH3CO hydrogenation predominantly leads to the formation of CH3CHO, with the reaction energy barriers on Co2C(111), (020), and (101) facets being 46, 90, and 41 kJ/mol lower than the formation of CH3COH, respectively. Notably, only on the Co2C(111) facet, the reaction is exothermic with a favorable energy release of 46 kJ/mol, whereas on the other facets, the reactions are endothermic. Additionally, CH3CHO can be desorbed from the system with an energy barrier of 78 kJ/mol and can undergo further hydrogenation to yield ethanol. 3.3 The formation mechanism of alcohol and aldehyde on Co/Co2C(111) interface On the basis of above, it can be concluded that Co2C(111) exhibits the highest favorability for alcohol formation compared to Co2C(101) and (020). In order to explore the influence of the Co and Co2C interface on alcohol selectivity, the Co/Co2C(111) interface model was constructed. This model integrates the previous analysis of Co2C(111) to investigate the synergistic effect between Co and Co2C. Alcohol formation on the Co(0001) facet is characterized by exothermic reactions. The total reaction energy barriers for Path 1 and Path 2 are 45 kJ/mol, while Path 3 exhibits a higher barrier of 144 kJ/mol. Hence, it is more probable for CH3CO to produce alcohols along Path 1 and Path 2, as illustrated in Fig. 7 a. In general, it is comparatively easy to hydrogenate CH3CO* on the Co(0001) surface, leading to the generation of alcohols and aldehydes. However, the formation of the CH3CO* species on a single Co surface poses challenges. According to research conducted by Hu et al. [29], the decomposition energy barriers of CHxCHyO* on the surface are around 0.8 eV. In comparison to the formation of oxygenated compounds, there is a higher preference for selectively producing olefin products, particularly long-chain hydrocarbons. The desorption of CH3CHO on the Co/Co2C(111) facet requires 87 kJ/mol of heat. Path 1, which involves the direct formation of alcohols, is hindered by a higher total reaction energy barrier of 201 kJ/mol and necessitates the absorption of 136 kJ/mol for alcohol production. In contrast, Path 2 involves a sequential three-step hydrogenation process to generate CH3COH, CH3CHOH, and CH3CH2OH, with reaction energy barriers of 37, 75, and 50 kJ/mol, respectively. Similarly, Path 3 also leads to the formation of alcohol through the successive hydrogenation steps of CH3COH, CH3CHOH, and CH3CH2OH, with reaction energy barriers of 72, 52, and 50 kJ/mol. These two routes exhibit favorable conditions for alcohol formation. Compared to the Co2C(111) facets, each step on the Co/Co2C(111) facet presents lower energy barriers. In conclusion, the Co/Co2C(111) facet proves advantageous in enhancing the selectivity of alcohols in the conversion of syngas to oxygenate compounds. Fig. 8 illustrates the initial states, transition states, and final states of the hydrogenation reaction of CH3CO to alcohol on the Co/Co2C(111) facet. It is observed that carbon-containing intermediates tend to adsorb on the Co atoms of the Co(0001) facet, while oxygen-containing endpoints are consistently positioned above the Co2C(111) facet and away from the Co(0001) direction. The α-C hydrogenation steps are depicted in Fig 8 (a-d), where H atoms are adsorbed on the Co(0001) facet: (a) adsorption at the bridge site, and (b-d) adsorption on the fcc site. Fig 8 (e-g) illustrates the O hydrogenation processes, where H atoms are adsorbed on the Co2C(111) facet and positioned on the fcc site. The desorption of alcohol takes place on the Co atoms at the junction of the Co/Co2C(111) interface. In conclusion, the hydrogenation positions are distributed on separate catalytic surfaces on both sides of the interface, leading to distinct hydrogenation behavior of oxygenated compound intermediates. The high alcohol selectivity observed on the interface catalyst model is attributed to the synergistic effect between Co and Co2C on the Co/Co2C(111) interface. Conclusion This study utilizes first-principles calculations to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the hydrogenation of oxygen-containing intermediates on (111) surface of Co2C nanospheres and (020) and (101) facets of nanoprisms Co2C, resulting in the production of alcohols and aldehydes during the conversion of syngas to oxygenated compounds. The oxygenated compounds on the surface of Co2C(020) are difficult to be hydrogenated. It can only be hydrogenated to aldehydes and desorbed, but not further hydrogenated to alcohols, while the aldehydes on the surface of Co2C(101) can be hydrogenated to alcohols more easily. On Co2C(111), the total reaction barrier of the three CH3CO* hydrogenation paths to CH3CH2OH are lowest of the three facets and exothermic, making it easier to generate oxygenated compounds. CH3CHO desorption has a lower energy barrier than continued hydrogenation to generate CH3CHOH or CH3CH2O, so it is easier to generate aldehydes. Additionally, the investigation into the catalytic conversion mechanism of the Co/Co2C(111) interface demonstrates that the selectivity of alcohols at the interface surpasses that of the individual Co(0001) or Co2C(111) surfaces. It is observed that during the hydrogenation of α-C, H atoms are all adsorbed on the Co(0001) surface. While in the step of O hydrogenation, all H atoms are adsorbed on the surface of Co2C(111). The hydrogenation positions are distributed on separate catalytic surfaces on both sides of the interface, leading to distinct hydrogenation behavior of oxygenated compound intermediates. This work provides theoretical support from a molecular chemical engineering perspective for the rational optimization of cobalt-based catalysts. By modifying the surface structure of cobalt-based catalysts and the Co/Co2C interface ratio, it is possible to selectively control the production of alcohols and aldehydes in the direct conversion of syngas to oxygenated compounds during catalyst preparation and reaction. coredata.dc:description: Syngas conversion to long chain alcohols and aldehydes by Co-based catalysts offers green route for synthesizing value-added chemicals. Cobalt carbides (Co2C) has been proven promoting oxygenates formation, and the Co/Co2C interface exhibited synergetic effects on increasing selectivity of higher alcohols. However, the underlying mechanism that determines the ratio of aldehydes and alcohols in oxygenate products is less understood. In this work, the hydrogenation of oxygenate intermediate was studied from first principles on metallic Co, Co2C surfaces and Co/Co2C interface to investigate the formation processes of alcohols and aldehydes. First-principles calculations show that: On Co2C(111) facet of Co2C nanosphere, aldehyde desorption as the final product has a slight advantage over its subsequent hydrogenation to alcohol; hydrogenation of oxygenate on Co2C(020) facet of Co2C nanoprism is difficult, whereas aldehyde on Co2C(101) facet of Co2C nanoprism is very easy to be hydrogenated to alcohol; and the synergistic effect between metallic and carbide surfaces on the Co/Co2C interface model promotes the selectivity of alcohol as the final product during hydrogenation of oxygenate intermediates. This study provides theoretical insights into the rational design of catalysts for controlling the selectivity between aldehydes and alcohols in syngas conversion to oxygenates.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical investigation of the selectivity of alcohols and aldehydes on Co-based catalysts in syngas conversion
